Index (S) » Numo » GSL » Sf
(no frames)
Class List Method List File List

Module: Numo::GSL::Sf

Defined in:
gsl_sf.c

Defined Under Namespace

Classes: MathieuWorkspace

Class Method Summary (collapse)

  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_Ai(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the Airy function Ai(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_Ai_deriv(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the Airy function derivative Ai'(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_Ai_deriv_e(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the Airy function derivative Ai'(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_Ai_deriv_scaled(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_A(x) Ai'(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_Ai_deriv_scaled_e(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_A(x) Ai'(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_Ai_e(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the Airy function Ai(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_Ai_scaled(x, [mode])

    These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_A(x) Ai(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_Ai_scaled_e(x, [mode])

    These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_A(x) Ai(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_Bi(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the Airy function Bi(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_Bi_deriv(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the Airy function derivative Bi'(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_Bi_deriv_e(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the Airy function derivative Bi'(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_Bi_deriv_scaled(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_B(x) Bi'(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_Bi_deriv_scaled_e(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_B(x) Bi'(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_Bi_e(x, [mode])

    These routines compute the Airy function Bi(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_Bi_scaled(x, [mode])

    These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_B(x) Bi(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_Bi_scaled_e(x, [mode])

    These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_B(x) Bi(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_zero_Ai(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function Ai(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_zero_Ai_deriv(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function derivative Ai'(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_zero_Ai_deriv_e(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function derivative Ai'(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_zero_Ai_e(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function Ai(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_zero_Bi(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function Bi(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) airy_zero_Bi_deriv(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function derivative Bi'(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_zero_Bi_deriv_e(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function derivative Bi'(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) airy_zero_Bi_e(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th zero of the Airy function Bi(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) angle_restrict_pos(theta)

    These routines force the angle theta to lie in the range [0, 2pi).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) angle_restrict_symm(theta)

    These routines force the angle theta to lie in the range (-pi,pi].
  • + (Numo::DFloat) atanint(x)

    These routines compute the Arctangent integral, which is defined as $hboxAtanInt(x) = int_0^x dt arctan(t)/t$ AtanInt(x) = int_0^x dt arctan(t)/t.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) atanint_e(x)

    These routines compute the Arctangent integral, which is defined as $hboxAtanInt(x) = int_0^x dt arctan(t)/t$ AtanInt(x) = int_0^x dt arctan(t)/t.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_I0(x)

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, I_0(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_I0_e(x)

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, I_0(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_I0_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order exp(-|x|) I_0(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_i0_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, exp(-|x|) i_0(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_I0_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order exp(-|x|) I_0(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_i0_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, exp(-|x|) i_0(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_I1(x)

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order, I_1(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_I1_e(x)

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order, I_1(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_I1_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order exp(-|x|) I_1(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_i1_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of first order, exp(-|x|) i_1(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_I1_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order exp(-|x|) I_1(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_i1_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of first order, exp(-|x|) i_1(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_i2_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of second order, exp(-|x|) i_2(x) Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_i2_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of second order, exp(-|x|) i_2(x) Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_il_scaled(l, x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of order l, exp(-|x|) i_l(x) Domain: l >= 0 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_il_scaled_array(lmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel functions exp(-|x|) i_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_il_scaled_e(l, x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel function of order l, exp(-|x|) i_l(x) Domain: l >= 0 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_In(n, x)

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, I_n(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_In_array(nmin, nmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the regular modified cylindrical Bessel functions I_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_In_e(n, x)

    These routines compute the regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, I_n(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_In_scaled(n, x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, exp(-|x|) I_n(x) Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_In_scaled_array(nmin, nmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the scaled regular cylindrical Bessel functions exp(-|x|) I_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_In_scaled_e(n, x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, exp(-|x|) I_n(x) Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Inu(nu, x)

    These routines compute the regular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, I_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Inu_e(nu, x)

    These routines compute the regular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, I_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Inu_scaled(nu, x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, exp(-|x|)I_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Inu_scaled_e(nu, x)

    These routines compute the scaled regular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, exp(-|x|)I_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_J0(x)

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, J_0(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_j0(x)

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, j_0(x) = sin(x)/x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_J0_e(x)

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, J_0(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_j0_e(x)

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, j_0(x) = sin(x)/x.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_J1(x)

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of first order, J_1(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_j1(x)

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of first order, j_1(x) = (sin(x)/x - cos(x))/x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_J1_e(x)

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of first order, J_1(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_j1_e(x)

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of first order, j_1(x) = (sin(x)/x - cos(x))/x.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_j2(x)

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of second order, j_2(x) = ((3/x^2 - 1)sin(x) - 3cos(x)/x)/x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_j2_e(x)

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of second order, j_2(x) = ((3/x^2 - 1)sin(x) - 3cos(x)/x)/x.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_jl(l, x)

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of order l, j_l(x), for $l geq 0$ l >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_jl_array(lmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the regular spherical Bessel functions j_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_jl_e(l, x)

    These routines compute the regular spherical Bessel function of order l, j_l(x), for $l geq 0$ l >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_jl_steed_array(lmax, x)

    This routine uses Steed's method to compute the values of the regular spherical Bessel functions j_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Jn(n, x)

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of order n, J_n(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Jn_array(nmin, nmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the regular cylindrical Bessel functions J_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Jn_e(n, x)

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of order n, J_n(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Jnu(nu, x)

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of fractional order nu, J_nu(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Jnu_e(nu, x)

    These routines compute the regular cylindrical Bessel function of fractional order nu, J_nu(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_K0(x)

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, K_0(x), for x > 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_K0_e(x)

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, K_0(x), for x > 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_K0_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order exp(x) K_0(x) for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_k0_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, exp(x) k_0(x), for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_K0_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order exp(x) K_0(x) for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_k0_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, exp(x) k_0(x), for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_K1(x)

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order, K_1(x), for x > 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_K1_e(x)

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order, K_1(x), for x > 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_K1_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order exp(x) K_1(x) for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_k1_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of first order, exp(x) k_1(x), for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_K1_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of first order exp(x) K_1(x) for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_k1_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of first order, exp(x) k_1(x), for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_k2_scaled(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of second order, exp(x) k_2(x), for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_k2_scaled_e(x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of second order, exp(x) k_2(x), for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_kl_scaled(l, x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of order l, exp(x) k_l(x), for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_kl_scaled_array(lmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel functions exp(x) k_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and x>0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_kl_scaled_e(l, x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel function of order l, exp(x) k_l(x), for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Kn(n, x)

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, K_n(x), for x > 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Kn_array(nmin, nmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel functions K_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Kn_e(n, x)

    These routines compute the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, K_n(x), for x > 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Kn_scaled(n, x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, exp(x) K_n(x), for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Kn_scaled_array(nmin, nmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the scaled irregular cylindrical Bessel functions exp(x) K_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Kn_scaled_e(n, x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified cylindrical Bessel function of order n, exp(x) K_n(x), for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Knu(nu, x)

    These routines compute the irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, K_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Knu_e(nu, x)

    These routines compute the irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, K_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Knu_scaled(nu, x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, exp(+|x|) K_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Knu_scaled_e(nu, x)

    These routines compute the scaled irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, exp(+|x|) K_nu(x) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_lnKnu(nu, x)

    These routines compute the logarithm of the irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, ln(K_nu(x)) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_lnKnu_e(nu, x)

    These routines compute the logarithm of the irregular modified Bessel function of fractional order nu, ln(K_nu(x)) for x>0, nu>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Y0(x)

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, Y_0(x), for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_y0(x)

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, y_0(x) = -cos(x)/x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Y0_e(x)

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of zeroth order, Y_0(x), for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_y0_e(x)

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of zeroth order, y_0(x) = -cos(x)/x.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Y1(x)

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of first order, Y_1(x), for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_y1(x)

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of first order, y_1(x) = -(cos(x)/x + sin(x))/x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Y1_e(x)

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of first order, Y_1(x), for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_y1_e(x)

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of first order, y_1(x) = -(cos(x)/x + sin(x))/x.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_y2(x)

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of second order, y_2(x) = (-3/x^3 + 1/x)cos(x) - (3/x^2)sin(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_y2_e(x)

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of second order, y_2(x) = (-3/x^3 + 1/x)cos(x) - (3/x^2)sin(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_yl(l, x)

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of order l, y_l(x), for $l geq 0$ l >= 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_yl_array(lmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the irregular spherical Bessel functions y_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_yl_e(l, x)

    These routines compute the irregular spherical Bessel function of order l, y_l(x), for $l geq 0$ l >= 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Yn(n, x)

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of order n, Y_n(x), for x>0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Yn_array(nmin, nmax, x)

    This routine computes the values of the irregular cylindrical Bessel functions Y_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Yn_e(n, x)

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of order n, Y_n(x), for x>0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_Ynu(nu, x)

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of fractional order nu, Y_nu(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Ynu_e(nu, x)

    These routines compute the irregular cylindrical Bessel function of fractional order nu, Y_nu(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_zero_J0(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_0(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_zero_J0_e(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_0(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_zero_J1(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_1(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_zero_J1_e(s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_1(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) bessel_zero_Jnu(nu, s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_nu(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_zero_Jnu_e(nu, s)

    These routines compute the location of the s-th positive zero of the Bessel function J_nu(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) beta(a, b)

    These routines compute the Beta Function, B(a,b) = Gamma(a)Gamma(b)/Gamma(a+b) subject to a and b not being negative integers.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) beta_e(a, b)

    These routines compute the Beta Function, B(a,b) = Gamma(a)Gamma(b)/Gamma(a+b) subject to a and b not being negative integers.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) beta_inc(a, b, x)

    These routines compute the normalized incomplete Beta function I_x(a,b)=B_x(a,b)/B(a,b) where $B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^a-1 (1-t)^b-1 dt$ B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^@a-1@ (1-t)^@b-1@ dt for $0 le x le 1$ 0 0, b > 0 the value is computed using a continued fraction expansion.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) beta_inc_e(a, b, x)

    These routines compute the normalized incomplete Beta function I_x(a,b)=B_x(a,b)/B(a,b) where $B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^a-1 (1-t)^b-1 dt$ B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^@a-1@ (1-t)^@b-1@ dt for $0 le x le 1$ 0 0, b > 0 the value is computed using a continued fraction expansion.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) Chi(x)

    These routines compute the integral $hboxSf.Chi(x) := Re[ gamma_E + log(x) + int_0^x dt (cosh(t)-1)/t]$ Chi(x) := Re[ gamma_E + log(x) + int_0^x dt (cosh(t)-1)/t] , where gamma_E is the Euler constant (available as the macro M_EULER).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) Chi_e(x)

    These routines compute the integral $hboxSf.Chi(x) := Re[ gamma_E + log(x) + int_0^x dt (cosh(t)-1)/t]$ Chi(x) := Re[ gamma_E + log(x) + int_0^x dt (cosh(t)-1)/t] , where gamma_E is the Euler constant (available as the macro M_EULER).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) choose(n, m)

    These routines compute the combinatorial factor n choose m = n!/(m!(n-m)!) exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) choose_e(n, m)

    These routines compute the combinatorial factor n choose m = n!/(m!(n-m)!) exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) Ci(x)

    These routines compute the Cosine integral $hboxSf.Ci(x) = -int_x^infty dt cos(t)/t$ Ci(x) = -int_x^infty dt cos(t)/t for x > 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) Ci_e(x)

    These routines compute the Cosine integral $hboxSf.Ci(x) = -int_x^infty dt cos(t)/t$ Ci(x) = -int_x^infty dt cos(t)/t for x > 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) clausen(x)

    These routines compute the Clausen integral Cl_2(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) clausen_e(x)

    These routines compute the Clausen integral Cl_2(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) complex_cos_e(zr, zi)

    This function computes the complex cosine, cos(z_r + i z_i) storing the real and imaginary parts in czr, czi.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) complex_dilog_e(r, theta)

    This function computes the full complex-valued dilogarithm for the complex argument z = r exp(i theta).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) complex_log_e(zr, zi)

    This routine computes the complex logarithm of z = z_r + i z_i.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) complex_logsin_e(zr, zi)

    This function computes the logarithm of the complex sine, log(sin(z_r + i z_i)) storing the real and imaginary parts in lszr, lszi.

    This function computes the complex sine, sin(z_r + i z_i) storing the real and imaginary parts in szr, szi.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) conicalP_0(lambda, x)

  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_CL_array(Lmin, kmax, eta)

    This function computes the Coulomb wave function normalization constant C_L(eta) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, Lmin > -1.

  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_wave_F_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x)

    This function computes the Coulomb wave function F_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, storing the results in fc_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_wave_FG_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x)

    This function computes the functions F_L(eta,x), G_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax storing the results in fc_array and gc_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_wave_FG_e(eta, x, L_F, k)

    This function computes the Coulomb wave functions F_L(eta,x), $G_L-k(eta,x)$ G_@L-k@(eta,x) and their derivatives F'_L(eta,x), $G'_L-k(eta,x)$ G'_@L-k@(eta,x) with respect to x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_wave_FGp_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x)

    This function computes the functions F_L(eta,x), G_L(eta,x) and their derivatives F'_L(eta,x), G'_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax storing the results in fc_array, gc_array, fcp_array and gcp_array.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_wave_sphF_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x)

    This function computes the Coulomb wave function divided by the argument F_L(eta, x)/x for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, storing the results in fc_array.

  • + (Numo::DFloat) erf_Q(x)

  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) erf_Q_e(x)

  • + (Numo::DFloat) erfc(x)

    These routines compute the complementary error function $erfc(x) = 1 - erf(x) = (2/sqrtpi) int_x^infty exp(-t^2)$ erfc(x) = 1 - erf(x) = (2/sqrt(pi)) int_x^infty exp(-t^2).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) erfc_e(x)

    These routines compute the quantity exp(x)-1 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) expm1_e(x)

    These routines compute the quantity exp(x)-1 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) exprel(x)

    These routines compute the quantity (exp(x)-1)/x using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) exprel_2(x)

    These routines compute the quantity 2(exp(x)-1-x)/x^2 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) exprel_2_e(x)

    These routines compute the quantity 2(exp(x)-1-x)/x^2 using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) exprel_e(x)

    These routines compute the quantity (exp(x)-1)/x using an algorithm that is accurate for small x.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) exprel_n(n, x)

    These routines compute the N-relative exponential, which is the n-th generalization of the functions gsl_sf_exprel and gsl_sf_exprel_2.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) exprel_n_e(n, x)

    These routines compute the N-relative exponential, which is the n-th generalization of the functions gsl_sf_exprel and gsl_sf_exprel_2.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) fact(n)

    These routines compute the factorial n!.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fact_e(n)

    These routines compute the factorial n!.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_0(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fermi_dirac_0_e(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_1(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 1, F_1(x) = int_0^infty dt (t /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fermi_dirac_1_e(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 1, F_1(x) = int_0^infty dt (t /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_2(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 2, F_2(x) = (1/2) int_0^infty dt (t^2 /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fermi_dirac_2_e(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of 2, F_2(x) = (1/2) int_0^infty dt (t^2 /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_3half(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_3/2(x)$ F_@3/2@(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fermi_dirac_3half_e(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_3/2(x)$ F_@3/2@(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_half(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_1/2(x)$ F_@1/2@(x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fermi_dirac_half_e(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral $F_1/2(x)$ F_@1/2@(x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_inc_0(x, b)

    These routines compute the incomplete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of zero, $F_0(x,b) = ln(1 + e^b-x) - (b-x)$ F_0(x,b) = ln(1 + e^@b-x@) - (b-x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fermi_dirac_inc_0_e(x, b)

    These routines compute the incomplete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of zero, $F_0(x,b) = ln(1 + e^b-x) - (b-x)$ F_0(x,b) = ln(1 + e^@b-x@) - (b-x).
  • + (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_int(j, x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an integer index of j, F_j(x) = (1/Gamma(j+1)) int_0^infty dt (t^j /(exp(t-x)+1)).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fermi_dirac_int_e(j, x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an integer index of j, F_j(x) = (1/Gamma(j+1)) int_0^infty dt (t^j /(exp(t-x)+1)).

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of -1.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) fermi_dirac_m1_e(x)

    These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an index of -1.

  • + (Numo::DFloat) gamma(x)

    These routines compute the Gamma function Gamma(x), subject to x not being a negative integer or zero.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) gamma_e(x)

    These routines compute the Gamma function Gamma(x), subject to x not being a negative integer or zero.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) gamma_inc(a, x)

    These functions compute the unnormalized incomplete Gamma Function $Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a real and $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) gamma_inc_e(a, x)

    These functions compute the unnormalized incomplete Gamma Function $Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a real and $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) gamma_inc_P(a, x)

    These routines compute the complementary normalized incomplete Gamma Function $P(a,x) = 1 - Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_0^x dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ P(a,x) = 1 - Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_0^x dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a > 0, $x ge 0$ x >= 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) gamma_inc_P_e(a, x)

  • + (Numo::DFloat) gamma_inc_Q(a, x)

  • + (Numo::DFloat) legendre_H3d(l, lambda, eta)

    These routines compute the l-th radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0, $l ge 0$ l >= 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) legendre_H3d_0(lambda, eta)

    These routines compute the zeroth radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space, $$L^H3d_0(lambda,eta) := over lambdasinh(eta)$$ L^@H3d@_0(lambda,eta) := sin(lambdaeta)/(lambdasinh(eta)) for $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) legendre_H3d_0_e(lambda, eta)

    These routines compute the zeroth radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space, $$L^H3d_0(lambda,eta) := over lambdasinh(eta)$$ L^@H3d@_0(lambda,eta) := sin(lambdaeta)/(lambdasinh(eta)) for $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) legendre_H3d_1(lambda, eta)

    These routines compute the first radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space, $$L^H3d_1(lambda,eta) := + 1} eta)over lambda sinh(eta)right) left(coth(eta) - lambda cot(lambdaeta)right)$$ L^@H3d@_1(lambda,eta) := 1/sqrt@+ 1@ sin(lambda eta)/(lambda sinh(eta)) (coth(eta) - lambda cot(lambdaeta)) for $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) legendre_H3d_1_e(lambda, eta)

    These routines compute the first radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space, $$L^H3d_1(lambda,eta) := + 1} eta)over lambda sinh(eta)right) left(coth(eta) - lambda cot(lambdaeta)right)$$ L^@H3d@_1(lambda,eta) := 1/sqrt@+ 1@ sin(lambda eta)/(lambda sinh(eta)) (coth(eta) - lambda cot(lambdaeta)) for $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) legendre_H3d_array(lmax, lambda, eta)

    This function computes an array of radial eigenfunctions $L^H3d_l( lambda, eta)$ L^@H3d@_l(lambda, eta) for $0 le l le lmax$ 0 <= l <= lmax.
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) legendre_H3d_e(l, lambda, eta)

    These routines compute the l-th radial eigenfunction of the Laplacian on the 3-dimensional hyperbolic space $eta ge 0$ eta >= 0, $l ge 0$ l >= 0.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) legendre_P1(x)

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomials $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) using explicit representations for l=1, 2, 3.

    These functions compute arrays of Legendre polynomials P_l(x) and derivatives dP_l(x)/dx, for l = 0, dots, lmax, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM @overload legendre_Pl_array(lmax,x).
  • + (Object) legendre_Pl_deriv_array

    These functions compute arrays of Legendre polynomials P_l(x) and derivatives dP_l(x)/dx, for l = 0, dots, lmax, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM @overload legendre_Pl_deriv_array(lmax,x).
  • + ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) legendre_Pl_e(l, x)

    These functions evaluate the Legendre polynomial $P_l(x)$ P_l(x) for a specific value of l, x subject to $l ge 0$ l >= 0, $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM.
  • + (Numo::DFloat) legendre_Plm(l, m, x)

Class Method Details

+ (Numo::DFloat) airy_Ai(x, [mode])

These routines compute the Airy function Ai(x) with an accuracy specified by mode.

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

static VALUE
numo_s_airy_Ai(int argc, VALUE *v, VALUE mod)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    gsl_mode_t c1;

    
    void *opt;

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_airy_Ai,NO_LOOP,1,1,ain,aout};

    
        if (argc==1) {
        c1 = GSL_MODE_DEFAULT;
    } else if (argc==2) {
        c1 = NUM2INT(v[1]);
    } else {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"invalid number of argument: %d for 1 or 2",argc);
    }
    opt = &c1; //mode

    


    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v[0]);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ (Numo::DFloat) airy_Ai_deriv_scaled(x, [mode])

These routines compute the scaled Airy function derivative S_A(x) Ai'(x). For x>0 the scaling factor S_A(x) is $exp(+(2/3) x^3/2)$ exp(+(2/3) x^(3/2)), and is 1 for x<0.

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_airy_Bi_deriv_scaled_e,NO_LOOP,1,3,ain,aout};

    
        if (argc==1) {
        c1 = GSL_MODE_DEFAULT;
    } else if (argc==2) {
        c1 = NUM2INT(v[1]);
    } else {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"invalid number of argument: %d for 1 or 2",argc);
    }
    opt = &c1; //mode

    


    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v[0]);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ (Numo::DFloat) airy_Bi_scaled(x, [mode])

These routines compute a scaled version of the Airy function S_B(x) Bi(x). For x>0 the scaling factor S_B(x) is $exp(-(2/3) x^3/2)$ exp(-(2/3) x^(3/2)), and is 1 for x<0.

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

+ (Numo::DFloat) angle_restrict_pos(theta)

These routines force the angle theta to lie in the range [0, 2pi).

Note that the mathematical value of 2pi is slightly greater than 2*M_PI, so the machine number 2*M_PI is included in the range.

Exceptional Return Values: GSL_ELOSS

Parameters:

  • theta (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

+ (Numo::DFloat) angle_restrict_symm(theta)

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_il_scaled_array(lmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the scaled regular modified spherical Bessel functions exp(-|x|) i_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_il_scaled_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)

#line 47 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_il_scaled_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

    

    if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;

    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_In_array(nmin, nmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the regular modified cylindrical Bessel functions I_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The start of the range nmin must be positive or zero. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: nmin >=0, nmax >= nmin Conditions: n=nmin,…,nmax, nmin >=0, nmax >= nmin Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]



3197
3198
3199
3200
3201
3202
3203
3204
3205
3206
3207
3208
3209
3210
3211
3212
3213
3214
3215
3216
3217
3218
3219
3220
3221
3222
3223
3224
3225
3226
3227
3228
3229
3230
3231
3232
3233
3234
3235
3236
3237
3238
3239
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 3197

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_In_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;
    int c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    

    
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_In_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

    

    if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;

    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_In_scaled_array(nmin, nmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the scaled regular cylindrical Bessel functions exp(-|x|) I_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The start of the range nmin must be positive or zero. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: nmin >=0, nmax >= nmin Conditions: n=nmin,…,nmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 3674

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_In_scaled_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;
    int c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    

    
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_In_scaled_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

    

    if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;

    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_j2,NO_LOOP,1,1,ain,aout};

    


    
#line 66 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop(&ndf,1,v0);
    
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_jl_array(lmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the regular spherical Bessel functions j_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 5240

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_jl_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;

    
    void *opt;
    

    
#line 47 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_jl_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

    

    if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;

    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_jl_steed_array(lmax, x)

This routine uses Steed's method to compute the values of the regular spherical Bessel functions j_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and $x geq 0$ x >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array. The Steed/Barnett algorithm is described in Comp. Phys. Comm. 21, 297 (1981). Steed's method is more stable than the recurrence used in the other functions but is also slower. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

numo_s_bessel_jl_steed_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{

    int c0;

    
    void *opt;
    

    
#line 47 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_jl_steed_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

    

    if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;

    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Jn_array(nmin, nmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the regular cylindrical Bessel functions J_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

2287
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 2245

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_Jn_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;
    int c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    

    
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Jn_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

    

    if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;

    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_kl_scaled_array(lmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the scaled irregular modified spherical Bessel functions exp(x) k_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0 and x>0, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Kn_array(nmin, nmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the irregular modified cylindrical Bessel functions K_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The start of the range nmin must be positive or zero. The domain of the function is x>0. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Conditions: n=nmin,…,nmax Domain: x > 0.0, nmin>=0, nmax >= nmin Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]



4158
4159
4160
4161
4162
4163
4164
4165
4166
4167
4168
4169
4170
4171
4172
4173
4174
4175
4176
4177
4178
4179
4180
4181
4182
4183
4184
4185
4186
4187
4188
4189
4190
4191
4192
4193
4194
4195
4196
4197
4198
4199
4200
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 4158

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_Kn_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;
    int c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    

    
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Kn_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

    

    if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;

    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Kn_scaled,NO_LOOP,1,1,ain,aout};

    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //n

    


    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v1);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Kn_scaled_array(nmin, nmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the scaled irregular cylindrical Bessel functions exp(x) K_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The start of the range nmin must be positive or zero. The domain of the function is x>0. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: x > 0.0, nmin >=0, nmax >= nmin Conditions: n=nmin,…,nmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

4656

4682
4683
4684
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 4642

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_Kn_scaled_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;
    int c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    

    
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Kn_scaled_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

    

    if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;

    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

    return sf_extract(vr);

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_yl_array(lmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the irregular spherical Bessel functions y_l(x) for l from 0 to lmax inclusive for $lmax geq 0$ lmax >= 0, storing the results in the array result_array. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Domain: lmax >= 0 Conditions: l=0,1,…,lmax Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

#line 47 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};

        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt = &c0; //lmax

    

    if (c0<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be lmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c0+1;

#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) bessel_Yn_array(nmin, nmax, x)

This routine computes the values of the irregular cylindrical Bessel functions Y_n(x) for n from nmin to nmax inclusive, storing the results in the array result_array. The domain of the function is x>0. The values are computed using recurrence relations for efficiency, and therefore may differ slightly from the exact values. Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

Parameters:

  • nmin (Integer)
  • nmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

2760
2761
2762
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 2720

static VALUE
numo_s_bessel_Yn_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;
    int c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    

    
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_bessel_Yn_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //nmin

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //nmax

    

    if (c0<0 || c1<0 || c0>c1) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be nmin>=0 && nmax>=0 && nmin<=nmax");
    }
    shape[0] = c1-c0+1;

    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ (Numo::DFloat) beta(a, b)

These routines compute the Beta Function, B(a,b) = Gamma(a)Gamma(b)/Gamma(a+b) subject to a and b not being negative integers. exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) beta_e(a, b)

+ (Numo::DFloat) beta_inc(a, b, x)

These routines compute the normalized incomplete Beta function I_x(a,b)=B_x(a,b)/B(a,b) where $B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^a-1 (1-t)^b-1 dt$ B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^@a-1@ (1-t)^@b-1@ dt for $0 le x le 1$ 0 <= x <= 1. For a > 0, b > 0 the value is computed using a continued fraction expansion. For all other values it is computed using the relation $I_x(a,b,x) = (1/a) x^a {}_2F_1(a,1-b,a+1,x)/B(a,b)$ I_x(a,b,x) = (1/a) x^a 2F1(a,1-b,a+1,x)/B(a,b).

Parameters:

  • a (Numo::DFloat)
  • b (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return



19778
19779
19780

    VALUE vr;
    

    

    

#line 50 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};

#line 66 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop(&ndf,3,v0,v1,v2);
    
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

These routines compute the normalized incomplete Beta function I_x(a,b)=B_x(a,b)/B(a,b) where $B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^a-1 (1-t)^b-1 dt$ B_x(a,b) = int_0^x t^@a-1@ (1-t)^@b-1@ dt for $0 le x le 1$ 0 <= x <= 1. For a > 0, b > 0 the value is computed using a continued fraction expansion. For all other values it is computed using the relation $I_x(a,b,x) = (1/a) x^a {}_2F_1(a,1-b,a+1,x)/B(a,b)$ I_x(a,b,x) = (1/a) x^a 2F1(a,1-b,a+1,x)/B(a,b).

+ (Numo::DFloat) Chi(x)

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) cos_err_e(x, dx)

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_CL_array(Lmin, kmax, eta)

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};

    opt = &c1; //kmax

    

    if (c1<0) {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"should be kmax>=0");
    }
    shape[0] = c1+1;

    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_coulomb_CL_e,NO_LOOP,2,3,ain,aout};

    


    
#line 66 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop(&ndf,2,v0,v1);
    
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_wave_F_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x)

This function computes the Coulomb wave function F_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, storing the results in fc_array. In the case of overflow the exponent is stored in F_exponent.

  • kmax (Integer)

  • x (Numo::DFloat)

  • kmax (Integer)

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_wave_FG_e(eta, x, L_F, k)

This function computes the Coulomb wave functions F_L(eta,x), $G_L-k(eta,x)$ G_@L-k@(eta,x) and their derivatives F'_L(eta,x), $G'_L-k(eta,x)$ G'_@L-k@(eta,x) with respect to x. The parameters are restricted to L, L-k > -1/2, x > 0 and integer k. Note that L itself is not restricted to being an integer. The results are stored in the parameters F, G for the function values and Fp, Gp for the derivative values. If an overflow occurs, GSL_EOVRFLW is returned and scaling exponents are stored in the modifiable parameters exp_F, exp_G.

Parameters:

  • eta (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • L_F (Numo::DFloat)
  • k (Integer)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [F.val, F.err, Fp.val, Fp.err, G.val, G.err, Gp.val, Gp.err, exp_F, exp_G, return]

This function computes the functions F_L(eta,x), G_L(eta,x) and their derivatives F'_L(eta,x), G'_L(eta,x) for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax storing the results in fc_array, gc_array, fcp_array and gcp_array. In the case of overflow the exponents are stored in F_exponent and G_exponent.

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) coulomb_wave_sphF_array(L_min, kmax, eta, x)

This function computes the Coulomb wave function divided by the argument F_L(eta, x)/x for L = Lmin dots Lmin + kmax, storing the results in fc_array. In the case of overflow the exponent is stored in F_exponent. This function reduces to spherical Bessel functions in the limit eta to 0.

Parameters:

  • L_min (Numo::DFloat)
  • kmax (Integer)
  • eta (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [fc_array[], F_exponent[], return]

(ja jb jc ma mb mc)

+ (Numo::DFloat) dilog(x)

These routines compute the dilogarithm for a real argument. In Lewin's notation this is Li_2(x), the real part of the dilogarithm of a real x. It is defined by the integral representation Li_2(x) = - Re int_0^x ds log(1-s) / s. Note that Im(Li_2(x)) = 0 for $x le 1$ x <= 1, and -pilog(x) for x > 1.

Note that Abramowitz & Stegun refer to the Spence integral S(x)=Li_2(1-x) as the dilogarithm rather than Li_2(x).

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return



10667
10668
10669
10670
10671
10672
10673
10674
10675
10676
10677
10678
10679
10680
10681
10682
10683
10684
10685
10686
10687
10688
10689
10690
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 10667

static VALUE
numo_s_dilog(VALUE mod,VALUE v0)
{
    VALUE vr;
    

    

    

#line 50 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_dilog,NO_LOOP,1,1,ain,aout};

    


    
#line 66 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop(&ndf,1,v0);
    
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) dilog_e(x)

These routines compute the dilogarithm for a real argument. In Lewin's notation this is Li_2(x), the real part of the dilogarithm of a real x. It is defined by the integral representation Li_2(x) = - Re int_0^x ds log(1-s) / s. Note that Im(Li_2(x)) = 0 for $x le 1$ x <= 1, and -pilog(x) for x > 1.

Note that Abramowitz & Stegun refer to the Spence integral S(x)=Li_2(1-x) as the dilogarithm rather than Li_2(x).

+ (Numo::DFloat) doublefact(n)

These routines compute the double factorial n!! = n(n-2)(n-4) dots. The maximum value of n such that n!! is not considered an overflow is given by the macro GSL_SF_DOUBLEFACT_NMAX and is 297. exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW

Parameters:

  • n (Numo::UInt32)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

17931

17933
17934
17935
17936
17937
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 17914

static VALUE
numo_s_doublefact(VALUE mod,VALUE v0)
{
    VALUE vr;
    

    

    

#line 50 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cUI,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_doublefact,NO_LOOP,1,1,ain,aout};

    


    
#line 66 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop(&ndf,1,v0);
    
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) doublefact_e(n)

These routines compute the double factorial n!! = n(n-2)(n-4) dots. The maximum value of n such that n!! is not considered an overflow is given by the macro GSL_SF_DOUBLEFACT_NMAX and is 297. exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW

Parameters:

  • n (Numo::UInt32)

+ (Numo::DFloat) ellint_D(phi, k, [mode])

These functions compute the incomplete elliptic integral D(phi,k) which is defined through the Carlson form RD(x,y,z) by the following relation,

D(phi,k) = (1/3)(sin(phi))^3 RD (1-sin^2(phi), 1-k^2 sin^2(phi), 1).

Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM

Parameters:

  • phi (Numo::DFloat)
  • k (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return



12012
12013
12014
12015
12016
12017
12018
12019

12031
12032
12033

12036

12038

12047

static VALUE
numo_s_ellint_D(int argc, VALUE *v, VALUE mod)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    gsl_mode_t c2;

    
    void *opt;
    

    

#line 50 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[2] = {{cDF,0},{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_ellint_D,NO_LOOP,2,1,ain,aout};

    
        if (argc==2) {
        c2 = GSL_MODE_DEFAULT;
    } else if (argc==3) {
        c2 = NUM2INT(v[2]);
    } else {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"invalid number of argument: %d for 2 or 3",argc);
    }
    opt = &c2; //mode

    


    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,2,v[0],v[1]);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ (Numo::DFloat) ellint_P(phi, k, n, [mode])

These routines compute the incomplete elliptic integral Pi(phi,k,n) to the accuracy specified by the mode variable mode. Note that Abramowitz & Stegun define this function in terms of the parameters m = k^2 and sin^2(alpha) = k^2, with the change of sign n to -n. Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM

Parameters:

  • phi (Numo::DFloat)
  • k (Numo::DFloat)
  • n (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 11838

static VALUE
numo_s_ellint_P(int argc, VALUE *v, VALUE mod)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    gsl_mode_t c3;

    
    void *opt;
    

    

#line 50 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[3] = {{cDF,0},{cDF,0},{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_ellint_P,NO_LOOP,3,1,ain,aout};

    
        if (argc==3) {
        c3 = GSL_MODE_DEFAULT;
    } else if (argc==4) {
        c3 = NUM2INT(v[3]);
    } else {
        rb_raise(rb_eArgError,"invalid number of argument: %d for 3 or 4",argc);
    }
    opt = &c3; //mode

    


    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,3,v[0],v[1],v[2]);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) ellint_P_e(phi, k, n, [mode])

These routines compute the incomplete elliptic integral Pi(phi,k,n) to the accuracy specified by the mode variable mode. Note that Abramowitz & Stegun define this function in terms of the parameters m = k^2 and sin^2(alpha) = k^2, with the change of sign n to -n. Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM

Parameters:

  • phi (Numo::DFloat)
  • k (Numo::DFloat)
  • n (Numo::DFloat)
  • mode (Integer) —

    The following precision levels are available: Numo::GSL::PREC_DOUBLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_SINGLE, Numo::GSL::PREC_APPROX.

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result.val, result.err, return]

    }
    opt = &c4; //mode

}

+ (Numo::DFloat) exp_mult(x, y)

These routines exponentiate x and multiply by the factor y to return the product y exp(x). Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

+ (Numo::DFloat) exprel(x)

These routines compute the quantity (exp(x)-1)/x using an algorithm that is accurate for small x. For small x the algorithm is based on the expansion (exp(x)-1)/x = 1 + x/2 + x^2/(2*3) + x^3/(2*3*4) + dots. Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EOVRFLW

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

+ (Numo::DFloat) exprel_2(x)

+ (Numo::DFloat) exprel_n(n, x)

These routines compute the N-relative exponential, which is the n-th generalization of the functions gsl_sf_exprel and gsl_sf_exprel_2. The N-relative exponential is given by,

exprel_N(x) = N!/x^N (exp(x) - sum_@k=0@^@N-1@ x^k/k!)

= 1 + x/(N+1) + x^2/((N+1)(N+2)) + ...
= 1F1 (1,1+N,x)

Exceptional Return Values:

Parameters:

  • n (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

static VALUE
numo_s_exprel_n(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;

    
    void *opt;
    

    

#line 50 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};

#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) exprel_n_e(n, x)

These routines compute the N-relative exponential, which is the n-th generalization of the functions gsl_sf_exprel and gsl_sf_exprel_2. The N-relative exponential is given by,

exprel_N(x) = N!/x^N (exp(x) - sum_@k=0@^@N-1@ x^k/k!)

= 1F1 (1,1+N,x)

+ (Numo::DFloat) fact(n)

These routines compute the factorial n!. The factorial is related to the Gamma function by n! = Gamma(n+1). The maximum value of n such that n! is not considered an overflow is given by the macro GSL_SF_FACT_NMAX and is 170. exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW

Parameters:

  • n (Numo::UInt32)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_fact,NO_LOOP,1,1,ain,aout};

    


    
#line 66 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

+ (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_0(x)

+ (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_int(j, x)

These routines compute the complete Fermi-Dirac integral with an integer index of j, F_j(x) = (1/Gamma(j+1)) int_0^infty dt (t^j /(exp(t-x)+1)). Complete integral F_j(x) for integer j Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EUNDRFLW, GSL_EOVRFLW

+ (Numo::DFloat) fermi_dirac_m1(x)

+ (Numo::DFloat) gamma(x)

These routines compute the Gamma function Gamma(x), subject to x not being a negative integer or zero. The function is computed using the real Lanczos method. The maximum value of x such that Gamma(x) is not considered an overflow is given by the macro GSL_SF_GAMMA_XMAX and is 171.0. exceptions: GSL_EDOM, GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EROUND

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

+ (Numo::DFloat) gamma_inc(a, x)

These functions compute the unnormalized incomplete Gamma Function $Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ Gamma(a,x) = int_x^infty dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a real and $x ge 0$ x >= 0. exceptions: GSL_EDOM

  • a (Numo::DFloat)

+ (Numo::DFloat) gamma_inc_P(a, x)

These routines compute the complementary normalized incomplete Gamma Function $P(a,x) = 1 - Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_0^x dt, t^(a-1) exp(-t)$ P(a,x) = 1 - Q(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) int_0^x dt t^@a-1@ exp(-t) for a > 0, $x ge 0$ x >= 0.

Note that Abramowitz & Stegun call P(a,x) the incomplete gamma function (section 6.5). exceptions: GSL_EDOM

Parameters:

  • a (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};

+ (Numo::DFloat) gammastar(x)

These routines compute the regulated Gamma Function Gamma^*(x) for x > 0. The regulated gamma function is given by,

Gamma^*(x) = Gamma(x)/(sqrt@2pi@ x^@(x-1/2)@ exp(-x))

= (1 + (1/12x) + ...)  for x \to \infty

and is a useful suggestion of Temme. exceptions: GSL_EDOM

Parameters:

  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

17476

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_gammastar,NO_LOOP,1,1,ain,aout};

    return sf_extract(vr);

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) gegenpoly_array(nmax, lambda, x)

This function computes an array of Gegenbauer polynomials $C^(lambda)_n(x)$ C^@(lambda)@_n(x) for n = 0, 1, 2, dots, nmax, subject to lambda > -1/2, $nmax ge 0$ nmax >= 0. Conditions: n = 0, 1, 2, … nmax Domain: lambda > -1/2, nmax >= 0 Exceptional Return Values: GSL_EDOM

Parameters:

  • nmax (Integer)
  • lambda (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

+ (Numo::DFloat) hydrogenicR(n, l, Z, r)

These routines compute the n-th normalized hydrogenic bound state radial wavefunction,

R_n := 2 (Z^@3/2@/n^2) sqrt@(n-l-1)!/(n+l)!@ exp(-Z r/n) (2Zr/n)^l

L^@{2l+1@}_@{n-l-1@}(2Zr/n).

where L^a_b(x) is the generalized Laguerre polynomial (Laguerre Functions). The normalization is chosen such that the wavefunction psi is given by $psi(n,l,r) = R_n Y_lm$ psi(n,l,r) = R_n Y_@lm@.

Parameters:

  • n (Integer)
  • l (Integer)
  • Z (Numo::DFloat)
  • r (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return



8684
8685
8686
8687
8688
8689
8690
8691
8692
8693
8694
8695
8696
8697
8698
8699
8700
8701
8702
8703
8704
8705
8706
8707
8708
8709
8710
8711
8712
8713
8714
8715
8716
8717
8718
8719
8720
8721
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 8684

static VALUE
numo_s_hydrogenicR(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2,VALUE v3)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;
    int c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    

    

#line 50 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[2] = {{cDF,0},{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_hydrogenicR,NO_LOOP,2,1,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //n

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //l

    


    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,2,v2,v3);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) hydrogenicR_e(n, l, Z, r)

These routines compute the n-th normalized hydrogenic bound state radial wavefunction,

R_n := 2 (Z^@3/2@/n^2) sqrt@(n-l-1)!/(n+l)!@ exp(-Z r/n) (2Zr/n)^l

L^@{2l+1@}_@{n-l-1@}(2Zr/n).

where L^a_b(x) is the generalized Laguerre polynomial (Laguerre Functions). The normalization is chosen such that the wavefunction psi is given by $psi(n,l,r) = R_n Y_lm$ psi(n,l,r) = R_n Y_@lm@.

Parameters:

  • n (Integer)
  • l (Integer)
  • Z (Numo::DFloat)
  • r (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result.val, result.err, return]

numo_s_hydrogenicR_e(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2,VALUE v3)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    int c0;
    int c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

#line 50 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"

    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[3] = {{cDF,0},{cDF,0},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_hydrogenicR_e,NO_LOOP,2,3,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //n

        c1 = NUM2INT(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //l

    


    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,2,v2,v3);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ (Numo::DFloat) hyperg_0F1(c, x)

These routines compute the hypergeometric function ${}_0F_1(c,x)$ 0F1(c,x). It is related to Bessel functions 0F1 = Gamma x^(1/2(1-c)) I_(c-1)(2 Sqrt) Gamma (-x)^(1/2(1-c)) J_(c-1)(2 Sqrt) exceptions: GSL_EOVRFLW, GSL_EUNDRFLW

  • x (Numo::DFloat)

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

+ (Numo::DFloat) hyperg_2F0(a, b, x)

These routines compute the hypergeometric function ${}_2F_0(a,b,x)$ 2F0(a,b,x). The series representation is a divergent hypergeometric series. However, for x < 0 we have ${}_2F_0(a,b,x) = (-1/x)^a U(a,1+a-b,-1/x)$ 2F0(a,b,x) = (-1/x)^a U(a,1+a-b,-1/x) exceptions: GSL_EDOM

Parameters:

  • a (Numo::DFloat)
  • b (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

+ (Numo::DFloat) hyperg_2F1(a, b, c, x)

These routines compute the Gauss hypergeometric function ${}_2F_1(a,b,c,x) = F(a,b,c,x)$ 2F1(a,b,c,x) = F(a,b,c,x) for |x| < 1.

If the arguments (a,b,c,x) are too close to a singularity then the function can return the error code GSL_EMAXITER when the series approximation converges too slowly. This occurs in the region of x=1, c - a - b = m for integer m. exceptions:

Parameters:

  • a (Numo::DFloat)
  • b (Numo::DFloat)
  • c (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • (Numo::DFloat) —

    return

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) hyperg_2F1_e(a, b, c, x)

These routines compute the Gauss hypergeometric function ${}_2F_1(a,b,c,x) = F(a,b,c,x)$ 2F1(a,b,c,x) = F(a,b,c,x) for |x| < 1.

If the arguments (a,b,c,x) are too close to a singularity then the function can return the error code GSL_EMAXITER when the series approximation converges too slowly. This occurs in the region of x=1, c - a - b = m for integer m. exceptions:

Parameters:

  • a (Numo::DFloat)
  • b (Numo::DFloat)
  • c (Numo::DFloat)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result.val, result.err, return]

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) legendre_array(norm, lmax, x)

These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre polynomials for 0 le l le lmax and 0 le m le l for $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1. The norm parameter specifies which normalization is used. The normalized P_l^m(x) values are stored in result_array, whose minimum size can be obtained from calling gsl_sf_legendre_array_n. The array index of P_l^m(x) is obtained from calling gsl_sf_legendre_array_index(l, m). To include or exclude the Condon-Shortley phase factor of (-1)^m, set the parameter csphase to either -1 or 1 respectively in the _e function. This factor is included by default.

Parameters:

  • norm (Integer) —

    Type of normalization to use. The possible values are: Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::NONE, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::SCHMIDT, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::SPHARM, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::FULL

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]



23990
23991
23992
23993
23994
23995
23996
23997
23998
23999
24000
24001
24002
24003
24004
24005
24006
24007
24008
24009
24010
24011
24012
24013
24014
24015
24016
24017
24018
24019
24020
24021
24022
24023
24024
24025
24026
24027
24028
 
# File 'gsl_sf.c', line 23990

static VALUE
numo_s_legendre_array(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1,VALUE v2)
{
    VALUE vr;
    
    gsl_sf_legendre_t c0;
    size_t c1;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[2];
    

    
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_legendre_array,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //norm

        c1 = NUM2SIZE(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //lmax

    

    shape[0] = gsl_sf_legendre_array_n(c1);
    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) legendre_array_e(norm, lmax, x, csphase)

These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre polynomials for 0 le l le lmax and 0 le m le l for $|x| le 1$ |x| <= 1. The norm parameter specifies which normalization is used. The normalized P_l^m(x) values are stored in result_array, whose minimum size can be obtained from calling gsl_sf_legendre_array_n. The array index of P_l^m(x) is obtained from calling gsl_sf_legendre_array_index(l, m). To include or exclude the Condon-Shortley phase factor of (-1)^m, set the parameter csphase to either -1 or 1 respectively in the _e function. This factor is included by default.

Parameters:

  • norm (Integer) —

    Type of normalization to use. The possible values are: Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::NONE, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::SCHMIDT, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::SPHARM, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::FULL

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)
  • csphase (Float) —

    To include or exclude the Condon-Shortley phase factor of (-1)^m, set the parameter csphase to either -1 or 1 respectively.

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], return]

    size_t c1;
    double c3;

    
#line 43 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    void *opt[3];
    

    
    size_t shape[1];
    

    ndfunc_arg_in_t ain[1] = {{cDF,0}};
    ndfunc_arg_out_t aout[2] = {{cDF,1,shape},{cI,0}};
    ndfunc_t ndf = {iter_legendre_array_e,NO_LOOP,1,2,ain,aout};

    
    
        c0 = NUM2INT(v0);
    opt[0] = &c0; //norm

        c1 = NUM2SIZE(v1);
    opt[1] = &c1; //lmax

        c3 = NUM2DBL(v3);
    opt[2] = &c3; //csphase

    

    shape[0] = gsl_sf_legendre_array_n(c1);
    
#line 64 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    vr = na_ndloop3(&ndf,opt,1,v2);
    
#line 68 "gen/tmpl/sf_basic.c"
    return sf_extract(vr);
}

+ (Numo::UInt64) legendre_array_index(l, m)

This function returns the index into result_array, result_deriv_array, or result_deriv2_array corresponding to P_l^m(x), P_l^'m(x), or P_l^''m(x). The index is given by l(l+1)/2 + m.

Parameters:

  • l (Integer)
  • m (Integer)

Returns:

  • (Numo::UInt64) —

    return

numo_s_legendre_array_index(VALUE mod,VALUE v0,VALUE v1)
{
    
    size_t c0;
    size_t c1;
    size_t c2;

    
    c0 = NUM2SIZE(v0);
    c1 = NUM2SIZE(v1);


#line 18 "gen/tmpl/sf_scalar.c"
    c2 = gsl_sf_legendre_array_index(c0,c1);

    
    return SIZE2NUM(c2);

}

+ (Numo::UInt64) legendre_array_n(lmax)

This function returns the minimum array size for maximum degree lmax needed for the array versions of the associated Legendre functions. Size is calculated as the total number of P_l^m(x) functions, plus extra space for precomputing multiplicative factors used in the recurrence relations.

Parameters:

  • lmax (Integer)

Returns:

  • (Numo::UInt64) —

    return

    c0 = NUM2SIZE(v0);


#line 18 "gen/tmpl/sf_scalar.c"
    c1 = gsl_sf_legendre_array_n(c0);

    
    return SIZE2NUM(c1);
    
#line 29 "gen/tmpl/sf_scalar.c"
}

+ ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) legendre_deriv2_alt_array(norm, lmax, x)

These functions calculate all normalized associated Legendre functions and their (alternate) first and second derivatives up to degree lmax for $|x| < 1$ |x| < 1. The parameter norm specifies the normalization used. The normalized P_l^m(x), their first derivatives dP_l^m(costheta)/dtheta, and their second derivatives d^2 P_l^m(costheta)/dtheta^2 are stored in result_array, result_deriv_array, and result_deriv2_array respectively. To include or exclude the Condon-Shortley phase factor of (-1)^m, set the parameter csphase to either -1 or 1 respectively in the _e function. This factor is included by default.

Parameters:

  • norm (Integer) —

    Type of normalization to use. The possible values are: Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::NONE, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::SCHMIDT, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::SPHARM, Numo::GSL::Sf::Legendre::FULL

  • lmax (Integer)
  • x (Numo::DFloat)

Returns:

  • ([Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::DFloat, Numo::Int32]) —

    array of [result_array[], result_deriv_array[], result_deriv2_array[], return]



24811
24812
24813
24814
24815
24816
24817
24818
24819
24820
24821
24822
24823
